bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 29, 1949

div1.p: Hench doubts that he will be able to attend the Reed Memorial Association meeting, but sends suggestions regarding Association business for his colleagues to consider. He recommends that Blossom Reed continue to receive Emilie Lawrence Reed's monthly pension after the latter's death. Hench informs Siler that the Cuban government has abandoned plans to preserve Camp Lazear and refused Hench's funds to temporarily protect Building No. 1. He suggests that the Association approach contacts in the U.S. War or Defense Departments to see if diplomatic or military channels might open the way for temporary preservation of the building.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, September 29, 1949
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER MINNESOTA
September 29, 1949
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
DR. HOWARD F. POLLEY
Colonel J. F. Siler
1835 Eye Street, Northwest
Washington 26, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I have your nice letter of September 7 about the November meeting
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. I wish indeed that I could be cer-
tain to attend this meeting but I am not at all sure that I can. I was in
Washington last week for about 36 hours and spent on hour with General and
Mrs. Kean.

In connection with our International Congress held last June, of
which I was General Chairman, I made so many trips to New York this spring
and in connection with our recent research work I was absent at so many
meetings that I used up more than my allotted time for absences from the
Clinic for the year.

About eleven weeks ago, as I believe General Kean told you, I de-
veloped a hemorrhage from an unsuspected duodenal ulcer, was knocked out four
weeks and then had five weeks' vacation; therefore it will be very difficult
for me to be absent from the Clinic in November. I have been invited to speak
in Boston on November 21 and 23. I have tentatively turned these invitations
down but if the matter is pressed or if I can see my way clear to do so, more
clearly than now, I may take a quick trip to Boston then and if so, I could
probably go or return by way of Washington. However that is Thanksgiving week
so that it might be better for me to come before.

I am so uncertain of all this and it is so likely that I will not go
that I think you had better plan the meeting this fall without me but I do want
to make three or four suggestions which I shall write to you in more detail
shortly. They are as follows:
1. As General Kean may have told you, Miss Blossom Reed wrote me that
her mother almost passed away a few months ago but once more recovered. Never-
theless, she is worse and necessitates extra expenditures on nursing care as she
is practically helpless and completely bedridden. Miss Blossom has gone to
considerable extra expense and is considerably worried financially. She wrote
me a nice little personal note wondering whether, at her mother's death, the
pension would continue to the Reed Children or be withdrawn. As far as I am
concerned, I am sure Walter Reed would consider the needs of his family above
all else, and I would certainly not be in favor of using the pension for some
small “monument” at the expense of lotting his children be in financial want.
Assuming that General Reed has enough retirement pay, and so forth, I would
vote to pass on the full pension to Miss Blossom upon the death of her mother,
using whatever of the principal might also be necessary to keep her comfortable.
Colonel J. F. Siler
- 2 -
September 29, 1949
2. Next year is the 50th anniversary of the work of Reed and his
colleagues. The matter of the placing of a modest wooden sign or bronze
plaque on the old hospital building where Walter Reed died is still unfinished
business. You will remember that General Truby and I tried to locate, two years
ago, the precise room in which he died but the plan has been so changed that
General Truby could not do this. In any event, it seems more appropriate to
have a memorial on the outside of the building. It was my understanding that the
commanding general of the military establishment where this building now is was
going to take care of that matter himself. Certainly he could put up a wooden,
nicely painted sign on the porch. If a small bronze plaque seems to be suitable,
The Surgeon General of the Army may have some ideas as to how this should be
handled.
3. In connection with the 50th Anniversary next year, it seems to me
that some notice in the press of this event would be appropriate. In connection
with our own recent researches, I have met and come to know rather well three or
four science writers such as Mr. William Laurence of the New York Times, Mr.
Steven Spencer of the Saturday Evening Post and others. Mr. Spencer is a very
able writer. He wrote up our work in the Saturday Evening Post and stopped
on his way through here a couple of weeks ago. I told him of the Reed anniversary
next year and suggested that he might like to write some sort of an article.
I have just had a reply which expresses his sincere interest. He wishes to
discuss the matter with the managing editor of the Post. I told him the names
of the survivors and if Spencer does not choose to write such an article, I am
sure I can stimulate one or two others to write. What is the opinion of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association toward this?
4. The matter of protecting Reed's Building No. 1 in Cuba. You may
remember that I was in Cuba the spring of 1948 and after considerable effort and
interviewing many hot-shots, including the Vice-President, they became presumably
very interested in permanently memorializing and protecting Building No. 1. We
even went so far as to draw up some informal plans for a building to cover
Building No. 1, for landscaping the adjacent grounds, etc. Knowing the manana
attitude of the Cubans, I persisted in offering to pay the expenses of putting
a galvanized iron covering over Building No. 1 as a temporary protection but with
many protestations of felicidad and sympatice, the Vice-President absolutely re-
fused to allow me to spend my money, insisting that the Cuban government would
do that at once as well as set aside funds for the memorial project. A bill was
introduced into the Cuban congress and was passed and I saw it published in the
Cuban newspapers allotting $50,000 for the project. Johnny Moran and I thought
that at long last all was well. But no! This occurred just a month before the
elections. The new regime was elected and I understand the whole thing is right
back where it started because the habit of a new Cuban government is simply to
ignore all financial commitments of the old one.

I don't know what to do further, at least at this distance, I may
be able to go to Cuba next spring but in the meantime, a hurricane may well
destroy Building No. 1 which has already survived several bad ones, including
one last year.

Secretary Johnson of the Defense Department visited the Clinic as a
patient many years ago. I think he was then assistant secretary. He happened
to hear my illustrated lecture on the conquest of yellow fever, became very in-
terested in it and later wrote me a note asking if he could help in any way.
That was before the war and I was proceeding with my own plans and did not call
upon him but it may be necessary now for us to ask the advice of Surgeon General
Bliss of the War Department to see whether they can, through diplomatic or mili-
tary channels, make some preliminary agreement so that at least an allocation of
$1,000 or $1,500 can be gotten to protect Building No. 1 temporarily with a
corregated iron covering until eventually some final disposition is made. Another
reason they wouldn't let me do it privately on my own was because the government
of Cuba, a couple of years ago, set aside Building No. 1 as a “national monument”
which means that no private individual can touch it without the approval of
the Cuban government.

These four items I should like to have considered by our colleagues
on the committee and I am enclosing copies of this letter which you might care
to send ahead of time to your colleagues so that they can have some preliminary
noted on the matter before the meeting.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
